intro: Acacia spinescens, commonly known as the prickly acacia, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often spiny stems and bipinnate leaves that are reduced to small, scale-like structures. The plant produces yellow, globular flower heads that bloom during the rainy season, attracting various pollinators. Its deep root system allows it to thrive in poor soils and withstand drought conditions. Acacia spinescens plays an important role in stabilizing soils and providing shelter for wildlife in its native habitat.

Its species is Acacia spinescens, a specific type of acacia known for its spiny appearance and adapted to arid environments.

It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often seen in open woodlands and shrublands. The plant is well adapted to the hot, dry climate of its native range. It plays an important role in the local ecosystem by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.

It has been cultivated in various regions across the country, particularly in southern and western states where the climate is arid or semi-arid. Although it is not native to India, it has been occasionally found escaping cultivation and establishing itself in natural habitats.
